title: Motorola made a Samsung phone from 2016

LG on the other hand unveiled their Velvet phone with a Snapdragon 765 inside, with the most interesting feature being a headphone jack. And I mean. - [James] Actually interesting. - Yeah, that alone makes me want it more than the Moto. I'm sorry Motorola, you were so cool once. You should try bringing back the Razr... Aah, you tried that. A security vulnerability in IOS has been actively exploited by hackers since at least January 2018, according to a report published by cyber security firm ZecOps. The bug allows an infected email to run malware on iPhones and iPads without even needing the user to open the email. The malware doesn't grant hackers control over the full device, but does allow control over emails in the Apple Mail app. - [James] That's enough. - Can you imagine. Someone just creating hundreds of drafts, which I then have to sort through to find the real ones? Horrible. That's the worst scenario I could come up with. - [James] Drunk drafting? - Apple says a patch is coming to fix the vulnerability but if you're worried, you can use Gmail or another email client because those aren't affected by this bug. And really you should have been doing that already. Apple Mail. (lips vibrating) And if you needed a final shove to switch from playing CS:GO to Valorant, the full source code for CS:GO and Team Fortress 2 has leaked. It's unclear how the code got out with some accusing Tyler McVicker of Valve News Network. McVicker denies this though and says he's co-operating with Valve's legal team to get to the bottom of this. Now the code is actually from 2017 so it might not be completely up to date. But the leak has ignited fears that bad actors could develop exploits based on the code and hack your PC while you're trying to headshot people. - [James] Acting career didn't turn out? Hack people. - Bad actors, oof! So you might wanna take a break from collecting hats or skins or whatever until the whole thing is sorted out. I think that's what those games are about. In response, developer Riot Games says it's launching an expanded bug bounty program which will pay those who discover security vulnerabilities. But no bounty is gonna make those characters as cool as the Overwatch Gang. Make an Overwatch movie Blizzard, just do it.
